'''Little Sonny''' (born '''Aaron Willis''', October 6, 1932, [[Greensboro, Alabama|Greensboro]], [[Alabama]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] [[harmonica]] player, [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/little-sonny-mn0000220715/biography |title=Little Sonny | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1932-10-06 |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref>  His early mentor and inspiration was [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]].  Nevertheless, Little Sonny stated that his [[nickname]] originated with his  mother. "[She] called me 'Sonny boy' from the time I can remember."<ref name="Metro"/> He has released eight albums, including a trio on a subsidiary of [[Stax Records]].<ref name="AMG"/> His 1973 release, ''Hard Goin' Up,'' reached the [[Top 40|Top 50]] in the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]].

==Biography==
He was born in 1932 and raised solely by his mother.<ref name="Concord">{{cite web|url=http://www.concordmusicgroup.com/artists/Little-Sonny/ |title=Little Sonny |publisher=Concord Music Group |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> He relocated  to [[Detroit]] in 1953.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Concord"/> At first he had no real interest in music until, as he explained, "But then I saw [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]]." Willis was "spellbound at the way he played. After the show I went home and practiced for hours. Every day after that I would practice until I got the sound I wanted." His daytime job was working in a [[Car dealership|used car lot]].<ref name="Concord"/>

His first professional appearance was at the Good Times Bar in Detroit, playing in [[Washboard Willie]]'s backing group. He put together his first band in March 1956.<ref name="Last">{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/music/Little+Sonny/+wiki |title=Little Sonny’s Biography – Free listening, concerts, stats, & pictures at |publisher=Last.fm |date=2013-11-26 |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> For the following fifteen years Little Sonny performed in numerous Detroit [[nightclub|clubs]], often boosting his earnings by [[photography|photographing]] customers between his on-stage appearances.<ref name="Concord"/> He ofttimes performed alongside [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Eddie Kirkland]] and [[Baby Boy Warren]].<ref name="AMG"/> Another club stalwart [[Eddie "Guitar" Burns]] provided accompaniment to Little Sonny on his debut [[single (music)|single]], "I Gotta Find My Baby" (1958), which was released by [[Duke Records]]. It was co-written with Little Sonny's wife, Maggie.<ref name="Metro"/> His follow-up release, "Love Shock" appeared on [[Excello Records|Excello]] [[record label|label]].<ref name="AMG"/> He received $25 for the latter track, before setting up his own label (Speedway Records) and selling sufficient copies of his next effort, "The Mix Up", to write off his production costs.<ref name="Concord"/>

Home recording his own tracks, in 1966 he leased "The Creeper" and "Latin Soul" to Revilot Records.<ref name="AMG"/> A later track, "Sonny’s Bag," became his first [[Top 40|Top 20]] [[hit single|hit]] in Detroit. By late 1969, Little Sonny finally recorded his debut [[album]], the predominately [[instrumental]], ''New King of Blues Harmonica,'' which he cut in less than six hours.<ref name="Concord"/> It was released on Enterprise, 
a subsidiary of [[Stax Records]].<ref name="Last"/> Despite their reputation for [[soul music]] productions, Little Sonny released three albums with them in the early 1970s. He also briefly appeared in their [[concert film]], ''[[Wattstax]]''.<ref name="AMG"/>

''Black & Blue'' (1972) and 1973's ''Hard Goin' Up'' followed, with Little Sonny using an Old Standby 34B harmonica.<ref name="Concord"/> A lean period ensued before the British label [[Sequel Records]] issued ''Sonny Side Up'' in 1995. His accompanists included [[keyboard instrument|keyboard]] player Rudy Robinson, and Little Sonny's guitarist son Aaron Willis, Jr., who had both played on ''Hard Goin' Up'' over twenty years previously.<ref name="AMG"/>

Little Sonny appeared at [[Black Hills State University]] on June 24, 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bhsu.edu/bh/news/currents/2000/xxiv25/index.html |title=Campus Currents |publisher=Bhsu.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref>

His photograph collection, housed in the basement of his Detroit home, includes shots of John Lee Hooker, Eddie "Guitar" Burns, Eddie Kirkland, [[Joe Hunter (musician)|Joe Hunter]], [[Eddie Willis]], [[Bobby Bland]], Washboard Willie, and Sonny Boy Williamson II. Little Sonny performed on October 4,  2008, at the Motor City Blues & Boogie Woogie Festival, in Detroit, with Eddie "Guitar" Burns, [[Otis Clay]] and [[Bobby Rush (musician)|Bobby Rush]].<ref name="Metro">{{cite web |url=http://www.metrotimes.com/music/story.asp?id=13310|title=Captured for life: A Detroit narrative in photos by a true Motor City original|author=Holdship, Bill |publisher=''[[Metro Times]]'' |accessdate=February 26, 2010}}</ref>

He is not to be confused with [[Little Sonny Warner]], [[Little Sonny Jones]], or Little Sonny Parker.

*''Blues with a Feeling'' (1996) - Sequel (UK)
